reviewText:
As someone who enjoyed Gone Home, Life is Strange, The Moon Sliver and Mind: Path to Thalamus, I thought I would enjoy this game too. Turns out I didn't.
First, it is stingy with the voice bits: I found interesting items that I thought would certainly trigger a monologue, such as the swing behind the house, which I thought would lead to a digression on the character's childhood. But nope, nothing happened when approaching that one and several other landmarks.
Second, it has one of the poorest implementations of invisible walls I've ever seen. There's for instance a big open wooden gate leading towards a house in the distance, but when you try to cross the threshhold, you simply can't advance anymore. Several other areas won't let you advance any further without even so much as fences to try and mask the invisible walls. Stinks of laziness by the dev's part.
Finally, the landmarks that do have audio bits are very far apart and don't have any indications, meaning you'll spend most of the playtime walking slowly and aimlessly, trying to guess where to go next.

The only thing this game has going for itself is the faily soothing and melancholic atmosphere, which it manages to pull off despite the outdated graphics. It's super short and, even though I got it in a sale at the Humble Store, I still feel cheated off my money, which is something I've felt with very few games ever.
If you like exploration games, Gone Home, A Story Of My Uncle, and Mind: Path to Thalamus are all much better options.

Bittersweet story about a woman returning to her broken childhood home. The title itself derives from a poem by T.S. Eliot, quoted below. It is a very short game but surprisingly rewards interest; voice acting and general ambience is spot on. Lacks many of the pretentions inherit in this genre of video gaming, namely in the form of Dear Esther. First playthrough time: 1 hour

Major Pros:
Emotional ‚Äúa day in the life‚Äù story experience
Calm no-rush feel with no time related events

Minor Pros:
Free exploration
Easy and fun-to-acquire achievements cover all dialog triggers
Main character is a little girl with an awesome elephant backpack who likes electronics and space

Major Cons:
Short with almost no replay value

Minor Cons:
The player isn‚Äôt given an explicit goal
It‚Äôs not always clear everywhere the player should go to trigger necessary dialog
No where does it tell you you can crouch, but you need to for a side dialog
image


The game is pretty short, but in that time the story is sweet. Almost everything is told through the dialog which is limited to only English and has no option for subtitles, making this a game you can really only get the most out of if you can hear and understand what‚Äôs being said. Some basics of the girl‚Äôs past can be gleaned without the dialog, but the player will miss her personal feelings on things and a lot of the detail. Since there is no branching or any sort of time dependent events, the game lacks any replay value unless you‚Äôre looking for achievements. The achievements are fun and completing them all means you‚Äôve found all the interactable items, dialog triggers, and ‚Äúsecrets‚Äù in the game, which gives a sense of completion. Partly because of there being no time related events, combined with the scenery and dialog, the game has a very relaxing feel to it that asks the player to simple sit and experience the story. The exploration is free form and everything except the last area (which unlocks after all the required dialog is triggered) can be done in any order. Along with this free form theme, the player isn‚Äôt given an explicit goal when starting the game. After exploring a while, it‚Äôll become clear that the goal is to trigger the story and once you‚Äôve found it, figure out a way to open the locked tool shed. There‚Äôs no puzzle to this part, you only have to explore the proper areas to trigger the necessary dialog before you‚Äôll be told where to get the shed key and it‚Äôll become obtainable. Another somewhat minor annoyance in the lack-of-direction department is that the player can indeed crouch in the game, but nothing tells you this. It‚Äôs only needed to get one side dialog, but for players trying to get the related achievement the game leaves you to figure that out on your own. Overall I found the story a wonderful although short experience. Players that are a fan of non-stereotypical female protagonists will also notice that the little girl in the story is a fan of electronics and space and has a gameboy in her room.

Note: This game has been provided to me for free for review purposes.OverviewHome is Where One Starts... is a short walking simulator that puts you in the shoes of a young girl, in a memory from childhood that the narrator, now grown up, remembers. You are free to walk about and find points of interest to trigger more memories.

The Pros:Vague but Inticing back-story - I cannot comment on it, as it is very short and I would spoil the whole plot, but the narrator gives little information about her past, but which can be deduced upon to reveal the situation.

Calming Music - While you explore, beautiful music will join you, which is quite relaxing in my opinion, and combined with the wonderful environments make this walking simulator enjoyable.

Easy Achievements - There are 7 achievements, 6 of which can be completed in a single playthrough, and most of them concentrating on paying atention to story details and acting upon them, or simply discovering interactable items or locations.

Cheap - While usually I don't factor in cost when reviewing a game, this short story also asks very little of your wallet.
Cons:Very Short - The game took me around 35 minutes to fully complete and explore, leaving very little replayability.

Little Narration - There are only about 10 short auditory narration triggers. The story told is more visual that audible. Could have been much more.

Mediocre Visuals - While the game looks good, and the lighting is just right, it suffers from low anti-aliasing and dodgy shortcuts, such as textures that rotate with you and flimsy foilage.
ConclusionThis is a good one-time-only exploration game with a lovely athmosphere and an apparently shallow, but deep backstory. If you are into short visual story-telling and walking simulators, pick this up, especially due to its low price.

reviewText:
Home is where One Starts is a short memoir of a young girl who missed her school bus one morning. Developed by David Wehle, I bought this game for the low price and the high rating that it had, I had a feeling that I wasn‚Äôt going to be disappointed, and I was right to feel that way.

Home is where One Starts begins when a young girl misses her school bus one morning and decides to roam around the trailer where she and her father live, and the beautiful nature that surrounds it, while she recounts how she felt that morning, and many other of the days she spent there. The game is a soft and straightforward story of exploration and discovery, but the narration that you unlock as you walk around tells you of a dark past of a scared, lonely girl, and her alcoholic father.

In terms of the main character, not much can be said. Details are kept so minimal that she could be absolutely any girl, but it is her feelings and wishes that are made clear to the player, us. As the morning goes by, the early sun shinning through the trees, you walk around finding lost toys and forgotten things, sometimes throw away on purpose, amongst the trash that is scattered around her trailer.

The game takes about 20 to 30 minutes to finish, and there are a few alternative endings depending on the things you were able to find, on the aspects of her story she ends up telling you about, and the direction that you decide to take when everything comes together and it ends.

All in all, Home is where One Stars is simply what the title tells you, a story of self reflection and perhaps self discovery. It is a short but satisfying story, with beautiful music and amazing graphics I originally wasn‚Äôt entirely expecting. For a mere 3.29$ on steam, I would say that it would be completely ridiculous for you not to go buy this gorgeous and touching game, and play it in one sitting.

Small con: The game has no save button, but considering how short it is, it is very easy to finish in one sitting.

Big pro: Gorgeous graphics.

reviewText:
Before you call me a heartless ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• who should be impaled and burned at a stake for disliking a game about such a touchy subject, let me explain.

I don't entirely hate this game, the concept isn't bad but the game is a really poor execution of what it intended to be.

Home is Where One Starts is a narrative first person 'game' which focuses on a broken home where a small girl lives with her drunk dad, now there's a strong subject in this already. So it's got the attention of people, now. Where the game fails isn't in the main story, which. Is still very underwhelming. But it fails in that some things you'll need to explore to learn about, and with the slow paced walking and boring looking visuals and lack of music to keep you occupied until you find these things. That's what makes me feel like this isn't worth my money

It says that this game is in the same style of other games like Gone Home or Dear Esther, I've never played Gone home, but i have played Dear Esther. And the thing with Dear Esther was that the narration in the game was focused on the main path, if you strayed off the path there wasn't anything to gain but for you to maybe admire some fine scenery or purely curriosity. And what Dear Esther had as an advantage for you to actually explore was it's interesting enviorment, atmosphere (and for an idea game) really good looks and that is what actually motivated you to explore further, even if there's little if even any gain for doing so.

This game faults in the thing that it's more open world, it's not liniar. You're free to walk around in an open plain but yet limited by invisible walls in this game, in Dear Esther the island you were on was very open, but it only allowed you to walk where you actually could, there wasn't any invisible walls or anything, at least not that i came across. They always made sure that if there was some place you couldn't go to, it was because it was either too steep hill, a fence blocking the path or just a vast ocean. This game is limited even if it offer exploration, with its invisible walls everwhere and frankly the visuals aren't that nice or too appealing to give you that desire to stop and admire the look, neither does it to explore as the are is very booring. I feel that you would have been best off in this if they focused more on telling the story a bit more, rather than letting you walk around on a small plain and find a few things here and there that you honestly might not care about. Like if you walk up to a graveyard the narrator (which is the girl) will more or less just say how she one time got spooked going there. I mean, sorry. But what is there for good in me knowing that? In Dear Esther they spoke more unclear, and with metaphores meaning you'd have to think, and puzzle the story the narrator explains toghether, so you can't just walk completely braindead, but in this game you can.

I feel this game failed to suck me in with any atmosphere and the fact that it cost almost half of what Dear Esther does (when not on sale), a game that has more land to explore, greater atmospher, better narration and more interesting vissuals just makes me unable to call this a worthy purchase. If you feel it's worth a try, i'd say go for it. There isn't anything in this game that'll occupy you for 2 hours, so you can refund the game after you've played it.


If this story was written by the dev who went through this as a child, then i'm sorry for what you've gone through. But i simply dislike the way the story is told. Not the story itself.

reviewText:
You get (assuming you aren't the sort of poopy-head that speedruns a walking simulator) about 1.5 hours worth of gameplay for ¬£2. For value for money, that's pretty good considering this is closer to a film than a traditional game.

Anyway... you are a young girl in the throes of younghood exploring the world of her drunken father and miserable child-dom in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• end of nowhere. You have 'areas of interest' which trigger wonderfully emotive voiceovers as you explore a memory(?) of a past experience - a siginficant time where she realised her youth was slipping away. There are invisible boundaries but this is cleverly played as a result of fear of leaving the area, missing school, fatherly retribution, etc. and you must conquer her fear somehow plot device but well done.

Looks-wise, yeah it's good. Environmental design and layout is pretty good, actually, considering it's a small sandbox. It feels like there's an equally grim and desolate world of beautiful sunlight and hay bales outside of the invisible boundaries. It also hints at that nostalgia of the 90s childhood where the world is wondrous and we all dreamed of a better, higher place like space, or how far birds can fly before school utterly crushed it in a miserable hate-fueled horrible education system. The sound design is also rather lovely and it knows when to shut up and just let you enjoy the ambient sounds. It's brevity is almost its strongest point. to the point, but still /alluding/ to beatings and hiding in bedrooms rather than blurting it out (bar one moment where you go looking for a 'hidden' item). It's cute, whimsical, sad, and like childhood, reflects that transient happiness/sadness/naivety. There's no pretense, no smarmyness or 'look at my huge depth'. It's to the point without losing the emotion it attempts to rise in ya. This is the thing about smaller developments with only WASD and right click - atmosphere and looks are bolsted and in a way which positively impacts upon the story

Sure, it's trying a little too hard to be other, better walking simulator deep and sad/happy games *cough*gone home*cough* but considering this is a two-person development with at least two playthroughs worth of gameplay that looks, sounds, and is quite lovely and never outstays its welcome and is literally two quid, you'd be silly not to buy it. Unless you don't like this sort of game in which case what are you doing here

-The game is beautiful and peaceful. The music is soft and the narrarator's voice is soothing.
- Easy enough to get achievements.

Cons:
- There are no subtitles and this only comes in English.
- Partial controller support, but in actuality it was a poor enough experience that I had to switch back to keyboard/mouse.

This is very much aimed at people who enjoyed games like Gone Home and Dear Esther- if you didn't like those then turn away now, there's nothing here for you. It's short (I doubt it will take anyone more than half an hour to complete) and more of a mood piece than an actual story, but it's creatively solid and quite poignant, giving the feeling of inhabiting a single, important memory.

Steam is becoming infamous for quick, lazy cash-grabs made of Unity assets; this isn't one of those. It's very clear that the game was made on a low budget, but the developer has worked smartly with their limited resources to make something with a cohesive and solid atmosphere, helped by great music and voice acting. And I absolutely loved the ending, for reasons I won't go into here- simple but powerful, like the rest of the game.

My only real complaint is that the game area is quite large and cluttered with trees and other objects; this gives you a wider area to explore but can also make it unnesecarily difficult to track down the points that trigger narration. I think a more compact world would have worked better.

Again: if you hated Gone Home, don't pick this up thinking you're going to like it. It's even more Gone Home than Gone Home was, if that makes sense. But if that game grabbed you and you're looking for a quick fix while you wait for Fullbright's follow up, definitely check this out.

I hope the developers go on and to bigger and better things, they've clearly got some real creative chops.

reviewText:
I don't mind short games. Not anymore, at least. And I don't mind walking simulators. There are some good ones out there like The Stanley Parable... and the Stanley Parable... and did I mention the Stanley Parable?

Home Is Where One Starts tells the story of a girl returning to an old trailer that she lived in with a drunk father, and you get to explore the area that she once lived in, as she recounts of her memories there. Under normal circumstances, this seems just like the kind of game I'd like, isn't it?

But these aren't normal circumstances.

First off, the world you visit, while pretty to look at is very stale after a while. There's only a handful of interactive items interspersed in this world that you can find, and actually finding them seems more like a chore, as the dog food and flask seemed more like a game of a scavenger hunt, but I wasn't promised a prize at the end.

Along with that, there really isn't anything unique to learn about the girl. Her dad was an abusive drunk, she liked space, and she liked to live out on her own, to create space from her father. Beyond that, she mentions little to nothing of her neighbors, her friends from school, her friends from out of school, her mother, her other relatives, the relationship her parents had. For a world she lived in, there aren't a lot of memories to be stimulated. Just a lot of things to look at with her voiceover telling you their significance.

If this game looks like the sort of artistic walking simulator that will whet your appetite, then by all means buy it. I'm sure you'd get more entertainment from it that I did. But I'm, unfortunately, giving this one a 5/10. I actually did want to like this game, but the lack of complexity or uniqueness makes this an ultimately forgettable experience.

As a little girl in a remote US town you have just missed the bus to school and decide to explore the surroundings of your house reminiscing about the experiences you had there: after a bit you'll muster the courage to go to your father's room, with whom you have a very difficult relationship, to get something that'll let you have at least a measure of freedom.

PROS:

-the story itself, as narrated by the protagonist, is simple but engaging enough: it also manages to have a few truly heartfelt moments

-the voice actress does a pretty good job

-while the graphics are quite simple they work well enough

-nice soundtrack

CONS:

-some textures are downright ugly

-the walking speed is horribly slow and this makes exploration a boring chore

-some items are hidden in really hard to find or remote places, this paired with the slow walking speed makes trying to find them a truly dull and frustrating affair

-for a game so interested in story and memories the fact quite a lot of interactive objects have no voiceovers attached is truly a missed chance

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=510905480

Home is Where One Starts is a decent story-driven walking simulator with a good concept and is able to provide some great food for thought to those willing to overlook its shortcomings. I did enjoy the story told by the girl and the moment of pure freedom the ending provides but the walks between important places/objects were dull at best due to the terrible walking speed paired with an explorable zone that, while not overly large, is big enough to make your lethargic movements a problem. The fact some objects are also very well hidden kinda goes against the fact the player'd be able to experience the story...why do I have to wander the woods aimlessly to find an important object? It's not fun and serves no real purpose.

As mentioned before the fact many objects can be picked up and examined but provide no voiceover is also a shame...sure I can imagine a story for them but I think it'd have been much better if the girl told us why they seem meaningful enough to be picked up and how they ended up where they are.

Home is Where One Starts sadly aeppeared after games like Dear Esther and Gone Home gave us much better examples in the genre and it suffers from it. That said I still enjoyed my time with the game and that's why I'm giving a thumbs up despite its problems.

Should you buy it? It depends. If you're ok with the aimless wandering or with following a guide so that you can cut on the painfully slow exploration then go for it, the story has enough merits to warrant a playthrough. If not you can safely skip it and go for better games in the genre. Just be sure to get it for the 1$ sale price or on a bundle.

reviewText: Does not live up to the high standards of other walking simulators such as Gone Home or Dear Esther. In terms of content there is literally less than 15-30mins of content (which they're honest about) but for such little content and playspace the designers have used it poorly. Many of the story elements are spread out too far among an overly large map that while attempting to give the illusion of exploration possibility, only ends up being a boring walk betwen each part. I played it for around 2 hours to get all achievements (and story content) but this did game did not deserve the press attention it was getting.\n\nNot knowing too much about the game I traded a $10-15 game that I otherwise wouldn't have played for it expecting something along the lines of Gone Home etc, or even Sunset. This is a 99c or less game even for what little that is well done. Dont make my mistake, just buy it instead instead of trading for it.

Also, I'm a little curious about the paper cranes. There were a few scattered around the area but there didn't seem to be any form of explanation or imortance.

Overall I'm glad I took the time time play through the story and enjoyed the achievements and finding the game secrets""

reviewText:
Expectedly Short, Unexpectedly Moving,
I was gladly surprised by how much I enjoyed this experience. It was gentle, peaceful (for the most part), and for me personally, nostalgic - in way both good and bad. The life of the protagonist was obviously difficult, but not without joy. I image them growing up to be an astronomer or electrician just as the game hinted they would. The narration was also very believable and nicely done. I continually found new things on following playthroughs that even kept it interesting past the developers intended playtime. (Apparently people are speed-running it... somehow).

I have always had a bit of a love-hate relationship with walking sims. I either adore them and their slow method of storytelling (as I did Rapture) or despise them (sorry folks, it was a great experience for some, I'm sure, but Dear Esther just didn't do it for me.) This one however was long enough to draw me in and I honestly wanted to see more of the young protagonists life and memory. This was kind of a flaw for me in that I would've loved to have more and the ending felt somewhat abrupt. I wonder how much of the game was inspired by experiences the developer had as a child - I can't image where else certain things in the game came from.

There are a few glitches that could use work - I occasionally walked through scenery, the game occasionally crashed, and appears to freeze when attempting to close, but this could be to do with my only being able to play on PC, and not owning an Oculus. I imagine that would not have such a problem.

Pros.
Beautiful graphics and music.
Believable narration well merged with the plot.
Subtle, but believable storytelling.
Empathetic protagonist.
Cons
Some mild gltiches with scenery
Occaisonal crashes with seeming no consistency.
Very short and with a quite abrupt ending.
